Heian-kyō is one of several former names for the city now known as Kyoto. In 794, Emperor Kammu established this city as Japan's capital. The move from Heijō-kyō to Heian-kyo marks the beginning of the Heian period of Japanese history.Hall, John Whitney. (1988). The Cambridge History of Japan, p. 516–517. ==City planning== The design of Heian-kyō mirrored grid pattern of Chang'an, which was the Tang Dynasty capital of China. ==Related pages== * Capital of Japan * Heian period ==References== ==Other websites== Category:Kyoto Category:Former capitals of Japan
